title.text: SUBJECT-VERB AGREEMENT IN RESPECTIVE COORDINATIONS AND CONTEXT-FREENESS

abstractContent.text: Langendoen (1977) advanced an argument against English being a context-free language involving cross-serial subject-verb agreement in respectively constructions such as (1).
(1) The man and the women dances and sing, respectively.
As noted by Pullum and Gazdar (1982), however, and acknowledged subsequently by Langendoen (personal communication), such examples are unacceptable, and the argument collapses on empirical grounds.
However, at least some speakers reject examples like (2) as well.
(2) The man and the women dance and sing, respectively.
This fact leads directly to a demonstration that there is, after all, a cross-serial dependency involving the grammatical number of subject NPs and verbs in respectively constructions.

However, it is not clear at present how representative such speakers are, and so instead of making claims about English in general, we will confine them to just those varieties of the language that stigma-tize examples like (2), which will be denoted as English1, leaving to one side any varieties of which this may not be true (English2).
